text: I'm Rakesh.

I'm currently serving as
the Dean of Harvard College.
And, just a little bit -
so I was born in India,
grew up here in New York City, in Queens.

I started off my academic
career at SUNY Binghamton,
transferred to Cornell.
Worked for a couple years
and came back here for graduate school,

and it's been, really being
part of higher education's
been a wonderful experience for me.
But I want to talk a little bit about
the sort of aspects
and I think all the opportunities
that higher education presents,
but also some of the challenges.

And I will share with you
some of the conversations

and work I've been doing
with undergraduates
who are here at Harvard.
And so I'm not going to try to present it
as sort of careful social science,
but I'm going to sort of share with you
their thoughts and points of view
and try to put some framing around it.
So, May is a great month for higher ed.

It's perhaps the most
important symbolic month.

So I know, especially for
David and Kathy to be here,
because it's our kind of version

of our kind of circle of
beginnings and endings, right?

So the high school
students who are coming in,
who've been filling applications out
and recommendations all last year
were making their decisions to come toward
at the beginning of this month,
and we are also sending our students out
in terms of commencement as well.

And I think we all know
the script by heart.

In a few months, we'll, as
we welcome the new students,

who will be deciding
what they want to study,
what courses they want to take
and who they want to live with
and be around while they're in college,
and we are also sending out our students

who have been shaped by
their experience here
at colleges and institutions,

and will shape their role as
citizens and citizen leaders
and the positions they'll take
after they leave institutions like ours.

And this process itself
is kind of anchored

in the history of our
nation and its founding.
I think it's anchored,
we can go back to the Northwest Ordinance,
but we can also go back before that,

to even the founding of
institutions like Harvard,
as the importance of education,
importance of the founding beliefs,
importance of engaged democracy,

and notions of that
somehow a nation like ours
was going to move away
from the notion of inherited privilege
to this notion of meritocracy.

And our nation has
invested countless hours

and countless dollars
into higher education
with these ideas in mind.

And I think the idea that a
good public school education

combined with a college
degree was really seen

for many of us as the example
par excellence of meritocracy,

and it can't be taken
for granted any longer.

I found this "Economist"
article a couple of years ago.

I remember seeing it, and I
was looking for the cover.
It had this notion of what it described
as America's new aristocracy.

And it was part of a critique
of selective institutions,

mostly motivated, if you got
a chance to read the article,

about the growing
inequality gap in the US.

And it was also I think in
some ways very misguided
because the institutions it was focused on
are really a very small microcosm

of the landscape of higher
education in the United States.
And while there's an oversized focus

on selective colleges in
our collective conscience,

these colleges are the
exception, not the rule.

If you look at around the 4,000,
depending on how you count,

institutions of higher
education in the United States,
colleges and universities, only 46 of them
have admissions rates less than 20%.

And in fact out of the 17 million
students in college today,
less than 300,000 will be in a residential
liberal arts and sciences experience,

probably like some of us or
many of us might have been in

in our own college or have
family or friends, children in.

And moreover, out of the 70%
of the students who are in,

American high school graduates
who enroll in college,
only 40% or so, 40% of that group
will attend community colleges.

A significant majority
are actually over 25,

and most will not finish
within five years.

And so I think it's really
easy to kind of focus
on our kind of little tiny tip

of the glacier of higher
education institutions,

and yet there is an enormous
amount of focus on them.
Elite schools continue to shape

so much of our cultural
understanding of college,
and there's some good parts to it,

but a double-edged part that
I'm going to talk about,

and I think the students'
experience as well.
So even going back for example,

this focus all the time
on these elite schools,
and I'm quoting Ernest Earnest,
what a great name, who wrote in his book,

"Academic Procession" at the
beginning of the 20th century,

quote, "To an amazing
degree, the pattern set
"by Harvard, Yale and Princeton after 1880

"became that of colleges
all over the country.

"The clubs, the social
organizations, the athletes,

"even the clothes and the
slang of the big three

"were copied by college
youth throughout the nation."

Another faculty member at
Yale, Canby, wrote in 1905.
He described Yale in the following way.
"Money counted.
"Social standing outside counted.
"Good looks counted also more,

"and so did good clothes
and the collegiate manner
"which required the slovenly use
"of expensive and well-cut garments."

By the 1890s, then Harvard,
Yale, and Princeton
had really become iconic institutions,

exerting a broad influence
on the national culture

and our definition of what it
meant to be a college student.
Athletics was another area.
Again, the first athletic match

was a rowing match
between Harvard and Yale,

and we all know I think
the impact that's had

on higher education and
the role that it plays
in the cultural authority
and understanding of higher education.

What's interesting about this
work is that more recently,

going back to "The Economist"
article is this critique
about the role of inequality in college,

and then increasingly
discussion of students
as colleges have tried to expand
through financial aid and other efforts,

bringing historically
underrepresented groups
into colleges and universities.
But what's interesting about that

is that that critique
which seems so recent
is a really old critique.
Schools like Harvard, Yale, Princeton,

other selective schools
have had financial aid
almost since their founding,
and there's always been this notion

that there's actually two
types of schools going on

at the same time in
institutions like this.
And part of that is that these works,

and we can look back at
the more classic works

to the more contemporary
ones, is that the idea

is that college is not only
a source of social mobility,

which I think a lot of
people often focus on,
but also can reinforce class inequalities.
And that idea, just to say, is not new.

There's almost 75 years
of academic literature

that highlights that many
university structures

are literally designed for
students privileged enough
to glide their way through school,

knowing full well that
they will have a job,
social resources, social capital,
and a high status position in society
waiting for them on the other end.

C. Wright Mills, a sociologist,
wrote in his famous book,

"The Power Elite", which
was written in the 1950s,
and I'll quote, "In the upper classes,
"it does not by itself mean much

"merely to have a degree
from an Ivy League school."
"That's assumed.

"The point is not Harvard,
but which Harvard?

"By Harvard, one means
Porcellian, Fly or A.D."
These are final clubs, all male clubs.
"By Yale, one means Zeta Psi
"or Fence or Delta Kappa Epsilon."
Jerome Karabel in his book, "The Chosen",

said there's always been
financial aid at schools

like Harvard and Yale, alongside
other selective schools,

but even in 1908, Harvard
had about 45% of its students
from public schools,

over 20% of the students
were from historically

what we would, they
were all male obviously,
but about 20% were identified as Jewish,
40% identified as Jewish at Columbia,
and also geographically from middle class
and also lower middle class families.
And so I think this notion
that there's always been two tracks

inside elite institutions
is really important,

and Nancy Malkiel also
finds the same thing
in discussing co-education battles

at schools like Harvard,
Yale, Princeton, Dartmouth,

and Anthony Jack most
recently finds again,
he talks about the two institutions

that exist in the book,
in "The Privileged Poor."
And I think what these books find
is I think, again, there's lots of books,
three or four common threads that you
would see through them, which is,
one is that there is one track
which provides a way for affluent,
mostly white, socially oriented-students

to isolate themselves from
their less privileged peers.
There's a second track, the second aspect,

which is historically
marginalized students

face greater challenges,
including achievement,
compared to their affluent counterparts.
And third, the dominant culture of college

rewards not just the
academically prepared,

but the socially prepared
for taking full advantage
of the opportunity structures
that could be offered by colleges.
And the question I think going back
to the theme of this conference is,
if we've known about this for so long,

and Harvard's about to have
it's 400th anniversary in 2036,
why does it persist?

Things persist because there's
interest in them persisting.

And I want to sort of just
put out some hypotheses
about why it persists.

So the first explanation
that things persist
is one that organizational sociology,

the field that I'm most
closely associated with,
talks about as organizational imprinting.
And the idea there is that organizations

are of necessity created
out of the specific context.
It could be technical, economic, cultural,
resources at their founding,
and that organizations are shaped
by historical specific resources
upon which their founders draw,

and that once founded,
these organizations survive

far into the future with
those founding structures

largely intact because the
latter continued to be efficient

or because of inertial
forces, such as tradition,
vested interest, or ideology,
or because of lack of competition.

And so here, when you think
about places like Harvard,
which is on the left of that picture,

when it was first founded,
Harvard based its admissions
on very subjective judgments

of students' character
and family background,

and their demonstrated
proficiency in Latin and Greek.
At their first commencement, for example,
which continued, this practice continued

well into the 1730s, so at
their 1642 first commencement,

there was a lavish feast,
which we would recognize.

There was lots of celebration,
which we would recognize,
and there was also tests given,
which we would not recognize.
But what was interesting
is that when the students were commenced,

they were not ordered
in alphabetical ways.
Rather, the first graduate,
the ordering of how degrees were announced

was not age or scholarship,
I quote, or the alphaber,

but according to the rank of
their families held in society.

And so they would go and
they would rank the status

of each of the families,
and this practice continued
well into the 1700s here.
The academics continued
to sort of be part of the discussion.

They added more languages,
they added math, et cetera,

but in many ways, this notion
that social status mattered
was really at their founding,

and persisted not just at
that first commencement,
but continued.
The other photo is the Yale football team
in the early 20th century.

If you look at the demographics
there, what you see again,

and this notion of imprinting
is really important.
So even last week,

when Harvard released its
Legacy of Slavery report,
you actually saw the same idea there.

Quote, "Not withstanding
Harvard's rhetorical commitment,"

and this was in reference
to the Civil War,

"to recruit a nationally
representative student body

"that would make model
political collegiality,

"the university sights remain
set on a white, upper crust.
"Harvard prized the admission
"of academically able Anglo-Saxon students
"from elite backgrounds,

"including wealthy
white sons of the south,

"and it restricted the enrollment
of so-called outsiders."
So, for the rest of the argument

that I want to sort of
just present a little here,
it's not just the imprinting,

but what does that imprinting
do to our students,

despite interventions as they
go through the experience?

And I don't want to say that
there's not good interventions.
There have been really significant ones,

but the persistence of
this kind of dual track

is the part that I want to sort
of talk about a little bit,

because even after an extensive
financial aid program,

Harvard College has
almost as many students
from the nation's top 0.1%,
so 0.1%, highest income families

as from the bottom 20%, and
more than half of the students

come from the top 10% of
the income distribution,

and the vast majority,
more than two-thirds,
come from the top 20%.
This is Raj Chetty and Friedman's work.
And at top colleges overall,

the proportion of students
from the richest one percent,

so this is sort of
defined as the Ivy plus,

of families has increased
during the last decade,

while the proportion from
the bottom 40% has decreased.
You know, sometimes it can look like

we're admitting more
students, but part of it
is that the definitions have changed.

So the Pell Grant
definition got much higher,

so it looks like we admit
more Pell Grant students.
And this is very understandable,

but getting into selective
institutions is very hard,

and really being poor and
all the sort of challenges

that implies makes it very
hard to get a good education,

and our K through 12
education is very uneven.
And so let me just set the context here.
I met with a group of Harvard students.

Most already knew each
other, and asked about how,
and I asked them how social class
impacted their Harvard experience.
And they were a diverse group of students.
Three self-identified as people of color,

four identified as male,
two identified as female.
One was a first year student,

two of them had taken time
off during the pandemic,

and they described their
experience, and they were,

they all uniformly were
glad to be at Harvard.

Several said the pandemic
had really given them

time to reflect on their
college experience,

what they valued, how they
realized they were changing,
and where they were finding themselves.
But

what was really interesting
is the high level of awareness
of their outsiderness.

Again, something that Jerome
Karabel, C. Wright Mills,
and others had pointed to.
The first thing is they pointed
to just the role of the context.
And I love this Laurel Ulrich quote:
"The context itself just sets a tone
"about who belongs and who doesn't.

"It is the ambient environment
of entering our dorms,

"looking at who's on
the walls, the library."
And the institution chooses selectively
to sort of highlight that history.
This was something, again, a critique
in the history of slavery report.

What was interesting to me
is that it was also critiqued
in Laurel Ulrich's report around gender,

and that was 25 years earlier,
and it could have been
like word for word the same arguments.

So as students say,
"Class is always there,
"but not always visible.
"It's only when the zones overlap.

"You sometimes notice it
when you're hanging out,

"but it becomes especially
evident during COVID.

"People fled to the
islands and summer homes.
"Others were still gyming."
These are all terms, I love, like,

learning from the students,
(crowd laughs)
which means they had gyms in their houses,

"and you followed your
peers on Instagram stories

"and could literally
peer into the other side.
"People who are FGLI have a hard time
"navigating upper class culture,
"especially when you first get here.

"The upper class people know
how to have more conversations.
"There are more conversations

"about where they've
gone and what they do.
"You are reminded about that the place
"was not originally designed for you.

"You eventually learn to
speak a different language,
"but feel like an imposter."

So students actually talk
about I think this notion
of high levels of awareness,

but also the performativity
aspects of what they're doing.

So that's one way that
the inequality persists.
The second way is on social comparison.
I won't read these quotes out loud,
but you can see that reference groups
start changing for our students.

They begin to see the life
that's possible before them,

and they see their own
attitudes and values shift,
and they're very conscious of that.

I think the idea that somehow
that we're doing some,

students understand they're
living in these spaces
and it becomes naturalized.

By the way, the new term
I learned was PJing,

which I thought had
something to do with pajamas,
but it turns out private jetting

(crowd laughs)
that students

become aware of this and
it naturalizes for them.
Lots of people are swayed.

It's not unconscious
knowing where I came from.
This is the fastest way to get ahead,
and it's a double-edged sword.
And a lot of this also mostly happens
outside of the classroom,

and that's the thing I think
is really quite important,

and that's exactly the same
story that C. Wright Mills said.

It's exactly the same story
that Nancy Malkiel points out.

It mostly plays out
outside of the classroom.
It shows up in leisure and job searches.

What are you doing when
you're not studying?

Career fairs, which job
occupations are you prepared for?
Which jobs are you aware of?
And then in its own strange way
works out in the sort of inequalities,

where delayed decisions
around graduate school,
because you want to take your MCATs again
but you don't have the resources,
so you have to work your job again,
and you start that cycle over again.
So I think this is something
that you have to become quite aware of.

Gender is also something that
students are quite aware,

but it was much more
complicated and nuanced
than I had expected, that it intersects

with a lot of other issues,
including class issues,
including status issues,

and the interplay is really
what happens really critically.
One of the students had read the work,

"Paying for the Party",
and she talked a lot

about the polished
femininity that was expected
of women or those who identify as women.

It really talked about how
it doesn't really make space

for other nonconforming or
other diverse identities.
But I think one of the things I would say

is that again, the
students are quite aware
of what's happening.
It's not unconscious.

I think there's a lot
of critical thinking.

So I want to just leave you
with some tentative assertions.

There's always been inequality
in higher education.

Who's poor has to be
understood in relative terms,
not absolute terms.

For most of its history,
elite and non elite coexist
in the same institution.
Extracurricular life and symbols
are the primary markers of class
in the undergraduate experience,

and taking advantage of the
opportunity of elite education

particularly manifest
in changing attitudes,
values, and career choices.
Now that's why it persists.
Last point.
Sometimes things change,
but it's really hard.

If we look at the social
movements in higher education,

there has been progress,
there has been movement,

and I'm going to leave you
with the final hypotheses.

I have no idea whether
these are true or not,
but when I look back at social movements

that moved institutions,
which are by definition

are systems designed not to
change, here's what I found.

National and global issues
reframed as campus issues

are positively associated
with institutional change.

You can look at apartheid,
you can look at civil rights,
you could look at some other movements,
environmental movements.
Student protests with faculty allies
are more likely to produce some change
than those that are just student-driven.

Campus movements led by
privileged students and alumni

are positively associated
with institutional change,
the most probably prevalent one
being the anti-Vietnam War protests.
And the fear of reactionary movements
led by privileged students and alumni
inhibit institutional change,
and I can talk about that during the panel

if anybody ever wants,
is interested in that.

And then finally, campus
movements anchored
in resource student organizations,

as opposed to petitions,
unorganized social movements,
referendums and social media

are positively associated
with institutional change,

and I think too often
people trying to make change

try too often with the social
media and the petitions,
rather than the sort of organizational,

sustained, ally-building,
alumni and faculty
creating those groups together

and creating allyship
between those groups.
So thank you so much for this time.
(crowd applauds)
